title: Near to Infinite loop when changing Group's name that has API token as Team Member

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:

The https://hackerone.com contains an iteration or loop with an exit condition that is near to infinite loop. If the loop can be influenced by an attacker, this weakness could allow attackers to consume excessive resources such as CPU or memory and even a DoS attack.

Description:
Hello Security team,

I have a test Enterprise Program https://hackerone.com/tonight_ptdkf enabled in my second H1 account. Last days I have been hunting on the program features and I have founded a weird behavior that can consume excessive resources on the platform.

Under the group management feature the program administrator can add a new group to segregate the permissions. The website runs the following function to create the group on the platform.

{
            Object(u.a)(a, e);
            var t = Object(c.a)(a);
            function a() {
                var e;
                return Object(o.a)(this, a),
                (e = t.call(this)).teamMemberGroups = new bO,
                e.teamMemberGroup = new fO,
                e.availablePermissions = [],
                e.currentTeam = new Lf,
                e.teamMembers = new PO,
                e.fetched = !1,
                e.savingTeamMemberGroupMembers = !1,
                e.selectedTeamMemberGroups = {},
                e
            }

{
                key: "new",
                value: function(e) {
                    var t = this;
                    this.loadResources(e).always((function() {
                        t.fetched = !0,
                        t.teamMemberGroup = new fO,
                        t.availablePermissions = t.currentTeam.get("available_permissions"),
                        t.trigger("change")
                    }
                    ))
                }

Once the group is created its can be read in JSON format throuhg the page https://hackerone.com/[YOUR_PROGRAM]/groups.json, as example below:

{
    "id":95038,
    "key":null,
    "name":"Testing",
    "team_members_count":0,
    "permissions":[
    ],
    "immutable":false,
    "team_member_ids":[
    ]
}

From the group management page the program administrator can add only users to that group, can't add API token to that group from there.

But the API token can be added to that group through https://hackerone.com/[YOUR_PROGRAM]/api.

Clicking on Manage groups is possible to add this API token to the previously created group.

Once you save that, you can read this API token permission/groups in JSON format too, just goint to https://hackerone.com/[Your_Program]/team_members/[The team member ID of your API toke].json

Just like before, the same data will be displayed.

{
    "id":95038,
    "key":null,
    "name":"Testing",
    "team_members_count":0,
    "permissions":[
    ],
    "immutable":false,
    "team_member_ids":[
    ]
}

Also, the group will be displayed under API Token page.

The issue comes when we change this group name that is linked to the API Token. So, in my test I changed from Testing to AAABC2.

More than 500 repeated JSON key {"id":95004,"key":null,"name":"AAABC2","team_members_count":0,"permissions":[],"immutable":false,"team_member_ids":[]} due to the loop issue.

As far as I understood from a static code analysis, the loop that is causing this issue is:

!function(e) {
    function t(t) {
        for (var n, s, l = t[0], o = t[1], c = t[2], m = 0, d = []; m < l.length; m++)
            s = l[m],
            Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty.call(r, s) && r[s] && d.push(r[s][0]),
            r[s] = 0;
        for (n in o)
            Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty.call(o, n) && (e[n] = o[n]);
        for (u && u(t); d.length; )
            d.shift()();
        return i.push.apply(i, c || []),
        a()
    }

Steps To Reproduce

  • Add a new group under group management of your program
  • Under the API Token, link your API to the group created in the previous step
  • Go back to the group management and change the group name

Note: Sometimes that server will not be able to handle the large repeated infomation in this loop when changing the group name and will response 500.

Impact

If the loop can be influenced by an attacker, this weakness could allow attackers to consume excessive resources such as CPU or memory and even a DoS attack.

activities.message: Hi @lucenaxpl0it - I'm discussing this submission internally with the HackerOne team. You will be updated as soon as there is additional information to share. Thanks for your patience!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @lucenaxpl0it - I'm discussing this submission internally with the HackerOne team. You will be updated as soon as there is additional information to share. Thanks for your patience!

activities.message:
Hi @0xcain 

Thank you for your reply. No problem, let me know when you have any update on it.

Thanks.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @0xcain

Thank you for your reply. No problem, let me know when you have any update on it.

Thanks.

activities.message: Hi @0xcain - thanks for your report! Although I agree that this is something we should fix, I don't think it has any security implications. For excessive resource consumption, you don't need this bug. The redirect happens in the browser, which means you could also create a loop in a script and access this page over and over again. Our rate limiting should protect us from it bringing us down and this loop doesn't change that. What do you think? Feel free to close this yourself in case you agree. Thanks!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @0xcain - thanks for your report! Although I agree that this is something we should fix, I don't think it has any security implications. For excessive resource consumption, you don't need this bug. The redirect happens in the browser, which means you could also create a loop in a script and access this page over and over again. Our rate limiting should protect us from it bringing us down and this loop doesn't change that. What do you think? Feel free to close this yourself in case you agree. Thanks!

activities.message:
Hi @jobert @0xcain 

Thank you again for your time on this report.

Regarding this statement: `The redirect happens in the browser, which means you could also create a loop in a script and access this page over and over again.` I don't agree because it seems to me that each loop iteration is being stored in your database, and to show you that, I have spent some time creating a script in python to retrieve the groups linked to the API token, and  I got the same large number of repeated groups as response from the API request `https://api.hackerone.com/v1/programs/44544`, that means that it happens in the browser when changing the group name, but every iteration is stored in database.

You can notice that running my script with my test account credential:

```javascript
import requests
import json

url= "https://api.hackerone.com/v1/programs/44544"

headers = {
  'Authorization': 'Basic ',
}

response = requests.request("GET", url, headers=headers)

convert_to_json = json.loads(response.text)

data = convert_to_json['data']['relationships']['members']
for member in data['data']:
      member = member['attributes']['groups']
      print(member)
```
* Save the above code as `.py` extension;
* Then run the code, `python file_name.py`

You'll get something like the following screenshot:

{F844304}

Video:



Thanks
@lucenaxpl0it

You can notice that running my script with my test account credential:

activities.message: Hi @lucenaxpl0it - whoops, my bad, looks like you're absolutely right - thanks for the additional evidence! We'll triage this and get it to an engineering team on our end to investigate and see if this could lead to excessive resource consumption. Thanks!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @lucenaxpl0it - whoops, my bad, looks like you're absolutely right - thanks for the additional evidence! We'll triage this and get it to an engineering team on our end to investigate and see if this could lead to excessive resource consumption. Thanks!

activities.message: Hi @lucenaxpl0it - this fell through the cracks on our end, we've just assigned this to an engineering squad to fix. We anticipate to have a fix out by next week. Thanks for your patience!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @lucenaxpl0it - this fell through the cracks on our end, we've just assigned this to an engineering squad to fix. We anticipate to have a fix out by next week. Thanks for your patience!

activities.message: Thanks again for bringing to our attention, it's much appreciated!
activities.markdown_message: Thanks again for bringing to our attention, it's much appreciated!

activities.message: Hi @lucenaxpl0it - thanks again for bringing this to our attention! We've pushed a fix for this. We'll clean up your groups within the next 24 hours. You shouldn't be able to add API users to the same group multiple times. Can you confirm this? Thanks!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @lucenaxpl0it - thanks again for bringing this to our attention! We've pushed a fix for this. We'll clean up your groups within the next 24 hours. You shouldn't be able to add API users to the same group multiple times. Can you confirm this? Thanks!

activities.message:
Hi @jobert

I've re-tested it and the issue is not reproducible on my end anymore.

I have created a new API `retest_1` and added it to the group `retest`, then I changed the group name multiple times, in all tests that I did, the application handled the loop iteration correctly, therefore, the fix is working just fine.

Also, I have added the previous group to the new API user, and at this time, even having multiple records in the database for the group `Testing1abc`, the application rendered only one in the UI.

{F908232}

The multiple groups previously created is just showing because you haven't cleaned this up yet, but you mentioned this will be done within 24 hours, so that's ok.

{F908241}

Thank you again for working on this and for the bounty awarded, I really appreciated it!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @jobert

I've re-tested it and the issue is not reproducible on my end anymore.

I have created a new API retest_1 and added it to the group retest, then I changed the group name multiple times, in all tests that I did, the application handled the loop iteration correctly, therefore, the fix is working just fine.

Also, I have added the previous group to the new API user, and at this time, even having multiple records in the database for the group Testing1abc, the application rendered only one in the UI.

The multiple groups previously created is just showing because you haven't cleaned this up yet, but you mentioned this will be done within 24 hours, so that's ok.

Thank you again for working on this and for the bounty awarded, I really appreciated it!

activities.message: Hi @lucenaxpl0it - thanks for confirming! I've redacted your API keys from the report. This report seems good to be disclosed! You can either agree to disclose it immediately or wait 30 days for it to be automatically disclosed. Happy hacking!
